Drone Project
By Nicholas Taylor
Teams:
Group 1: Security – Prevent and defend against hacking attempts. These can be done through physical if they obtain access to a drone, through Wi-Fi attacks, RF attacks, GPS attacks, etc. Apply  Zero Trust model.

Group 2: Resilience – Prevent and overcome communication interruptions, hardware failures, software failures, etc. Create contingencies, countermeasures, redundancies, etc. Try to eliminate any SPOF (Single Point of Failure) that you can.
				Zero Trust Model
The main ideology of the Zero Trust Model is: ​
A small compromise you make in trust can cause; disasters huge financial losses, etc.​
Applying Zero Trust Model:
Treat devices on a network like strangers, they must prove their identity before you can trust them.
If something can be exploited, someone will exploit it.

	     Eliminating Single Points of Failure
“A 'Single Point of Failure' refers to a vulnerable component in a system that, if it fails, can cause the entire system to fail. ” (sciencedirect.com)

Common strategies of eliminating and reducing points of failure:
Redundancies – If a technology goes down, have another in its place
Contingencies – Have a backup plan 
Countermeasures – Actively take measures when needed reduce interruptions
Damage control – If something goes wrong, minimize resulting damages 


How to get started:
All Groups: 
Read the ICCCN paper
Group 1:

Find vulnerabilities in the current configuration. If something isn’t specified, assume it isn’t implemented.

Group 2:
Look at what could go wrong with the current configuration and think of worst-case scenarios. 




			Current configuration
How could this configuration be sabotaged  and what could go wrong? How about the sensors on the drone? What could happen during a sabotage?
